awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Zero Emission Nested Loop Reforming for High Purity Hydrogen Production
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to meet the growing demand for reduction of carbon emissions. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPS) indicates that the major sources of emissions in the U.S. are from transportation, electrical generation, and industrial processes. These sources collectively constitute 79% of the 6.5 billion metric tons of emissions in 2017. This SBIR project will enhance the leading hydrogen production technology to become more efficient and release zero carbon emissions.  The hydrogen technology innovation will also help meet the growing demand in the hydrogen market, valued at $136 billion and growing at 8% annually, as well as unlock hydrogen in new industries, such as electrical generation, that in the past have deemed hydrogen production as a non-viable option due in part to the carbon emissions.  

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to construct an innovative hydrogen reformer that is more efficient than the leading hydrogen production technology while releasing zero carbon emissions. The main technical risk the research will address is the integration of technically complex systems into a seamless hydrogen generator. The proposed project will break the integrated system into components which will be evaluated prior to integration, thus reducing the overall project risk. Upon successful construction and testing of the proposed system, PureTech will have demonstrated the technical and economical feasibility of the proposed system. This proof will allow PureTech to embark on a path to build large-scale hydrogen production systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hydrogen is considered a form of clean energy because it is a rich fuel source containing no carbon, and thus releases no greenhouse gas emissions on consumption. It is less known that the typical production of hydrogen through steam methane reforming emits high volumes of greenhouse gases. The concept of a zero-emission hydrogen production system is therefore highly sought after, and much success has been found by water splitting, or hydrolysis. However, hydrolysis does not currently match the efficiency and cost effectiveness of steam methane reforming, and current electrical infrastructure is incapable of meeting current hydrogen demands through hydrolysis alone. PureTech?s proposed solution is the advancement of methane reforming technology to eliminate GHG emissions while still maintaining or even improving upon the high efficiency of traditional methane reforming processes. The result is a zero-emission nested-loop (ZEN) reformer which continuously reforms the methane and carbon dioxide cycles methane to facilitate the conversion of water into hydrogen and oxygen through two key chemical reactions. The SBIR Phase I award for the research and development of the ZEN reformer for high purity hydrogen production was structured based on those two key reactions that make up the overall system. Each component focuses on one of the two key reactions and represents one of the two nested loops referenced by the project title.

The first loop and the first component is a circulating bed reforming component in which hydrogen is produced in a circulating bed of catalyst and carbon dioxide adsorbent. Methane from the second component is reacted with process steam to form hydrogen and carbon dioxide, the latter of which is adsorbed onto the fluidized solid bed and separated from the hydrogen product. The hydrogen product is cooled and sent to storage while the solids with adsorbed carbon dioxide are fed to a vacuum-assisted regenerator. Upon entering the regenerator, the carbon dioxide is desorbed from the solids and sent to the second component, while the solids are returned to the primary reforming vessel and again met with the steam methane mixture for further adsorption, thus completing the first loop.

The second component is a photocatalytic reactor in which carbon dioxide and water are exposed to high intensity ultraviolet radiation in the presence of a proprietary photocatalyst for the purpose of converting the carbon dioxide into methane for supply back to the first component, thus forming the second process loop. Byproduct oxygen is also produced in the photocatalytic reaction of water and carbon dioxide. This oxygen could serve many additional purposes but is outside the scope of this research. Combining these two key components successfully means reducing the overall reactants to water and the overall products to hydrogen and oxygen, effectively eliminating emissions.

Catalyst preparation was subcontracted to experts in the field for the purpose of fine-tuning a recipe and preparing a catalyst with the desired properties. The catalyst was successfully prepared with the appropriate ratios of catalytic and auxiliary elements. When applied to the second component, however, the conversion rate of carbon dioxide into methane was incapable of meeting the demands of the first component. The company will conduct independent, self-funded research to improve the catalyst for effective application before continuing toward commercialization.

The construction and testing of the first component suffered many setbacks including, but not limited to subcontract cancellations, supplier changes and long lead times due to COVID-19 shutdowns, shortages of raw materials, and very significant cost increases between proposal and award periods. Nonetheless, the first component was constructed and physical testing of the system did take place. The research completed in this award indicates that the selected mixture of methane reforming catalyst and carbon dioxide adsorbent material are suitable for fluidization in the ZEN reformer based on several keyfactors including adsorption capacity and rate, reforming reaction kinetics, and attrition rates. The solids were successfully cycled through the reactor and regenerator in such a way that adequate reaction time and adsorption/desorption times are possible at the desired rates without the solid attrition that would be seen with traditional reforming catalysts. The thermomechanical and reactive testing of the system was not completed in the allotted award time, but further self-funded independent testing at targeted operating conditions is planned to complete the development of the system after the closure of this Phase I award.

In summary, resolution of the following two issues will need to be found before proceeding to commercialization: (1) more time is required to complete the thermal and reactive testing of the first component and (2) the photocatalyst needs further development to match the production rates of the first component. Both of these issues will be further investigated through independent, self-funded research by PureTech.
